pullRequest.body:
Co-authored-by: @kmill , @thorimur 

---

Code provided by Kyle Miller on [Zulip](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/270676-lean4/topic/linters/near/419681022).
Used in #10235, moved to a separate PR to reduce rebuilds there.

<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body: :v: urkud can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
bors r-
Canceled.
I tried the new version in #10235 and the linter timeouts.

I guess (without any confirmation), it happens because it starts erasing proofs in `typeOf e`, `typeOf (typeOf e)` etc. I wonder why Lean accepts this function as non-`partial` while it timeouts (almost?) every time.

I think I figured it out: when it constructs `sorryAx ty` with `ty : Prop`, now `sorryAx` itself (with these level parameters) is a `Prop` since it has type `∀ ty : Prop, ty`.

I think if you set the option `(skipConstInApp := true)` for `transform` then everything should be good.

By the way, `Meta.transform` is `partial`, which is where the infinite loop can come in.
Thanks! I tested on my branch and it works!

I assume that it was already delegated.
bors merge

Build failed (retrying...):
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8353444113/job/22865171711)

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8354047142/job/22866753525)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8354047142/job/22866753330)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8354047142/job/22866753214)

Note that the expression may still contain proofs after `eraseProofs`, as there might be proofs in the type of a proof within `e` (and this winds up in `e` proper, as an argument to `sorryAx`).

I'm struggling to think of any practical (non-contrived) examples, however. Plus, the current implementation has the advantage of preserving the type. Do you think this could ever be an issue in the application at hand?

If you wanted to *really* make sure there were no proofs in the expression, you could write
```suggestion
partial def eraseProofs (e : Expr) : MetaM Expr :=
  Meta.transform e
    (pre := fun e => do
      if (← Meta.isProof e) then
        return .done (← mkSyntheticSorry <|← (← inferType e).eraseProofs)
```
but at the cost of potentially not preserving the type. Otherwise, it might simply be worth adding a caveat in the docstring explaining the guarantee, e.g.:
> Note that only proofs which were already present in the original expression are guaranteed to be erased. If any proofs are present in the *type* of any proof within `e`, these will be introduced via `sorryAx`, and so the resulting expression may not technically be completely proof-free.

In that case, it may also be worth noting
> `eraseProofs` preserves the type of `e`.
@kmill What do you think? Should we have 2 functions?

Are you sure that this doesn't preserve the type @thorimur ? Proof irrelevance should mean that the type is the same, up to defeq.

For efficiency (and incidentally avoiding `partial`), I would instead change that line to
```
return .continue (← mkSyntheticSorry (← inferType e))
```

True, I'm talking about preservation on the nose (`BEq`) and should have specified. (I thought it was nice that (as far as I could see) all mdata and the like was preserved.) Defeq is probably all we really need.

Ah, I see, `.continue` makes more sense there!
I tried to follow suggestions in this thread. Please have another look.

This looks good to me.

One thing to be aware of is that `Meta.transform` doesn't instantiate metavariables. That's fine — you just need to be sure to `instantiateMVars` before running `eraseProofs` (assuming you're working with expressions that might have metavariables). There's a possible gotcha, where if you're using this function in a local context whose local variables might have metavariables, `inferType` here could result in metavariables.

I'm tempted to say "it's OK that this is sensitive to metavariables", and that this latter issue is unlikely to cause applications of this function issues. It only pops up if `inferType` results in a metavariable whose type contains a proof. I'm just writing this here to record the possibility.

Should we merge then?

bors d+

Let's merge.
bors merge

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(Lean/Expr): define `Expr.eraseProofs`

I tried the new version in #10235 and the linter timeouts.

I guess (without any confirmation), it happens because it starts erasing proofs in `typeOf e`, `typeOf (typeOf e)` etc. I wonder why Lean accepts this function as non-`partial` while it timeouts (almost?) every time.

I think I figured it out: when it constructs `sorryAx ty` with `ty : Prop`, now `sorryAx` itself (with these level parameters) is a `Prop` since it has type `∀ ty : Prop, ty`.

I think if you set the option `(skipConstInApp := true)` for `transform` then everything should be good.

By the way, `Meta.transform` is `partial`, which is where the infinite loop can come in.

I assume that it was already delegated.
bors merge
